entry.title: The Family Proceedings Fees (Amendment) (No.2) Order 2007

ukm:Subject.Value: SUPREME COURT OF ENGLAND AND WALES

category.term: SUPREME COURT OF ENGLAND AND WALES

entry.summary: This Order amends the Family Proceedings Fees Order 2004 (S.I. 2005/3114) as follows—

entry.title: The Gambling Act 2005 (Commencement No. 6 and Transitional Provisions) (Amendment) (No. 2) Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order amends the Gambling Act 2005 (Commencement No. 6 and Transitional Provisions) Order 2006 (S.I. 2006/3272) (“the Principal Commencement Order”).

entry.title: The Medicines for Human Use (Administration and Sale or Supply) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order makes further amendments to certain Orders relating to the administration and sale or supply of medicines for human use.

entry.title: The Children Act 2004 Information Database (England) Regulations 2007

ukm:Supersedes.dc:title: The Children Act 2004 Information Database (England) Regulations 2007

entry.summary: These Regulations are made under section 12 of the Children Act 2004 (“the Act”) and apply to the establishment and operation of a database in England, which will be known as “ContactPoint”. They revoke (at regulation 14) the Information Sharing Index (England) Regulations 2006 (S.I. 2006/983) which relate to a database that was established for the purpose of conducting data trials prior to the establishment of the database to which these Regulations relate. The Regulations come into force seven days after the day on which they are made.

entry.title: The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Markets in Financial Instruments) (Amendment No. 2) Regulations 2007
entry.summary: These Regulations, which amend the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Markets in Financial Instruments) Regulations 2007 (S.I. 2007/126) (“the principal Regulations”), implement in part Directive 2004/39/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 April 2004 on markets in financial instruments (OJ No L 145, 30.4.2004, p.1) (“the Directive”). The Directive is also implemented by other statutory instruments including the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities) (Amendment No. 3) Order 2006 (S.I. 2006/3384) and by the Financial Services Authority (“the FSA”) using powers under the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (c. 8) (“the Act”).

entry.title: The Conservation (Natural Habitats, etc.) (Amendment) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007
entry.summary: These Regulations amend the Conservation (Natural Habitats etc.) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1995 (“the 1995 Regulations”) which make provision for implementing Council Directive 92/43/EEC on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora (“the Habitats Directive”) (O.J. No L206, 22.7.92, p.7).

entry.title: The Money Laundering Regulations 2007
entry.summary: These Regulations replace the Money Laundering Regulations 2003 (S.I. 2003/3075) with updated provisions which implement in part Directive 2005/60/EC (OJ No L 309, 25.11.2005, p.15) of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. A Transposition Note setting out how the main elements of this directive will be transposed into UK law is available from the Financial Services Team, HM Treasury, 1 Horse Guards Road, London SW1A 2HQ. An impact assessment has also been prepared. Copies of both documents have been placed in the library of each House of Parliament and are available on HM Treasury’s website (www.hm-treasury.gov.uk).

entry.title: The Civil Proceedings Fees (Amendment) (No.2) Order 2007

ukm:Subject.Value: SUPREME COURT OF ENGLAND AND WALES

category.term: SUPREME COURT OF ENGLAND AND WALES

entry.summary: This Order amends the Civil Proceedings Fees Order 2004 (S.I. 2004/3121).

entry.title: The Mental Health Act 2007 (Commencement No. 1) Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order is the first commencement Order made under the Mental Health Act 2007 and brings into force section 45 of that Act in relation to England and Wales. Section 45 amends section 23 of the Mental Health Act 1983 (c.20) in relation to the delegation by National Health Service foundation trusts of their power to discharge patients from compulsion under the Act.

entry.title: The North East Lincolnshire Primary Care Trust (Change of Name) (Establishment) Amendment Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order amends the North East Lincolnshire Primary Care Trust (Establishment) Order 2000, which established the North East Lincolnshire Primary Care Trust.

entry.title: The Employment Income (Meaning of Securities) Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order amends the meaning of the expression “securities” in section 420(1) of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 to include arrangements falling within section 48A of the Finance Act 2005 (alternative finance arrangements: alternative investment bond). This Order reflects the change in law resulting from the enactment of section 48B(3) of the Finance Act 2005 which was inserted by section 53 of the Finance Act 2007.

entry.title: The Income Tax (Exemption of Minor Benefits) (Amendment) Regulations 2007
entry.summary: Section 210 of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (“the Act”) allows the Treasury to make regulations which remove minor benefits provided to an employee by an employer from the charge to income tax otherwise arising under Chapter 10 of Part 3 (taxable benefits: residual liability to charge) of the Act.

title.div: The Trinity College, Carmarthen (Designated Institutions in Higher Education) (Wales) Order 2007 / Gorchymyn Coleg y Drindod, Caerfyrddin (Sefydliadau Dynodedig mewn Addysg Uwch) (Cymru) 2007

div.p: Trinity College, Carmarthen is designated by this Order for the purposes of section 129 of the Education Reform Act 1988. This means that it is eligible to receive support from funds administered by a higher education funding council and is to be treated as an institution within the higher education sector for the purposes of the Education Acts.

Dynodir Coleg y Drindod, Caerfyrddin gan y Gorchymyn hwn at ddibenion adran 129 o Ddeddf Diwygio Addysg 1988. Mae hyn yn golygu ei fod yn gymwys i dderbyn cymorth o gyllid a weinyddir gan gyngor cyllido addysg uwch a'i fod i'w drin fel sefydliad o fewn y sector addysg uwch at ddibenion y Deddfau Addysg.

entry.title: The Company and Business Names (Amendment) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007
entry.summary: These Regulations amend the Company and Business Names Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1984 (S.R. 1984 No. 49). Regulation 2 provides that the word “Government” cannot form part of—aa company’s registered name; orba business name,without the prior written approval of the Department.

entry.title: The National Police Records (Recordable Offences) (Amendment) Regulations 2007
entry.summary: These Regulations amend the Schedule to the National Police Records (Recordable Offences) Regulations 2000. The Schedule lists those offences which are recordable but which do not attract the possibility of a custodial sentence.

entry.title: The Social Security Contributions and Benefits (Northern Ireland) Act 1992 (Modification of Section 4A) Order 2007
entry.summary: This Order modifies section 4A of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits (Northern Ireland) Act 1992 in consequence of the modifications of the provisions of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (“ITEPA”) by paragraphs 3 and 4 of Schedule 3 to the Finance Act 2007. Those paragraphs extend the scope of Part 2 of ITEPA to managed service companies. Chapter 9 of that Part contains the substantive provisions on the provision of worker’s services through managed service companies.

entry.title: The Magistrates’ Courts (Parenting Orders) (Amendment) Rules 2007
entry.summary: These Rules amend the Magistrates’ Courts (Parenting Orders) Rules 2004 (S.I. 2004/247(L. 3)) (“the principal Rules”). They amend Schedules 1 and 2 of the principal Rules consequent upon the amendment of section 20 of the Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 (“the 2003 Act”) by section 98 of the Education and Inspections Act 2006 (“the 2006 Act”, rules 4 and 5 respectively). They amend Schedule 3 of the principal Rules (rule 6). Rule 3 inserts rules 7 to 10 of, and rule 7 inserts Schedules 5 to 8 to, the principal Rules. These provisions set out the procedure in relation to parenting orders under sections 26A and 26B of the 2003 Act, and provide forms in relation to these parenting orders.

entry.title: The Categories of Gaming Machine Regulations 2007

ukm:Supersedes.dc:title: The Categories of Gaming Machine Regulations 2007

entry.summary: Section 236 of the Gambling Act 2005 (“the Act”) requires regulations to be made defining four classes of gaming machine, to be known as Categories A, B, C and D. “Gaming Machine” is defined in section 235 of the Act. These Regulations provide the necessary definitions for each category, A to D. These Regulations also provide definitions for five sub-divisions of the Category B machine, to be known as sub-categories B1, B2, B3, B3A and B4.

entry.title: The Family Procedure (Adoption) (Amendment) Rules 2007
entry.summary: These Rules make minor amendments to the Family Procedure (Adoption) Rules 2005 that are consequential upon the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (c.9) coming into force.

entry.title: The Group Relief for Overseas Losses (Modification of the Corporation Tax Acts for Non-resident Insurance Companies) (No. 2) (Amendment) Regulations 2007
entry.summary: The Finance Act 2006 (c. 25: “FA 2006”) extended the provisions in the Corporation Tax Acts concerning loss relief for groups of companies (known as “group relief”). Prior to that Act, the relief was available only to U.K. resident companies or companies with a permanent establishment in the U.K.. Following the EC Court of Justice’s decision in Marks and Spencer p.l.c. v Halsey (H.M. Inspector of Taxes) in 2005, FA 2006 included provisions allowing certain non-resident companies (an “EEA company”) to surrender losses to a U.K. resident company in the same group. The loss must be calculated following the provisions of the Corporation Tax Acts.
